author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Tracy Bennett enters the variety puzzle pantheon with a twisty challenge.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Tracy Bennett is a member of the Games editorial staff of The New York Times, in charge of Wordle. She is also a puzzle constructor, but this is her first foray into variety puzzles. It’s a terrific solve, and looks like it was a blast to make. It has a big dollop of wit and the kinds of bits and pieces that a creative mind comes up with and reserves for the right setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: No One Can Stop Talking About Justice John Marshall Harlan
description: John Roberts and Clarence Thomas have the “colorblind” Constitution all wrong.
content: If nothing else, the Supreme Court’s decision in Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard is a victory for the conservative vision of the so-called colorblind Constitution — a Constitution that does not see or recognize race in any capacity, for any reason.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: As a Mexican Fighter Rises, U.F.C. Hopes Others Will Follow
description: Even with a long history of fighters of Mexican heritage in combat sports, Brandon Moreno is the first U.F.C. champion born in Mexico. His rise comes as the company looks to expand its reach.
content: Brandon Moreno, the Ultimate Fighting Championship’s flyweight champion, sat on a gym mat and stretched his lower body while music from the Argentine pop group La K’onga blared through speakers overhead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Switzerland and Austria, Both Traditionally Neutral, Join a German-Led Air Defense Initiative
description: The Sky Shield initiative is aimed at strengthening Europe’s air defenses to deal with threats highlighted by Russia’s assault on Ukraine.
content: GENEVA — Switzerland and Austria, two countries with strong traditions of foreign-policy neutrality, signaled their intention on Friday to join a German-led initiative aimed at strengthening Europe’s air defenses to deal with threats highlighted by Russia’s assault on Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: These 2024 Candidates Have Signed Up For Threads, Meta’s Twitter Alternative
description: The bulk of the G.O.P. field is there, with some notable holdouts: Donald J. Trump, the front-runner, and his top rival, Ron DeSantis.
content: While the front-runners in the 2024 presidential race have yet to show up on Threads, the new Instagram app aimed at rivaling Twitter, many of the long-shot candidates were quick to take advantage of the platform’s rapidly growing audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Watchers to Parse June Jobs Report Closely
description: How much more the Federal Reserve raises interest rates this year will hinge on the strength of the economy — particularly the labor market.
content: Federal Reserve policymakers are debating how much further they need to raise interest rates to ensure that inflation speedily returns to a normal pace, and that calculus is likely to depend heavily on the job market’s strength.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Ex-Amazon Manager Sentenced to 16 Years in Prison in $9 Million Theft Scheme
description: Federal prosecutors said that Kayricka Wortham, a former operations manager at an Amazon warehouse in Georgia, was the leader of a group that stole money from the company.
content: In her role as an operations manager at an Amazon warehouse in Georgia, Kayricka Wortham had the authority to approve new vendors and their invoices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah A. Topol and Glenna Gordon
title: The America That Americans Forget
description: As tensions with China mount, the U.S. military continues to build up Guam and other Pacific territories — placing the burdens of imperial power on the nation’s most ignored and underrepresented citizens.
content: On the weekends, when Roy Gamboa was a little boy, his grandfather woke him before dawn. He would pour some coffee into a bowl of rice, and that would be the boy’s breakfast. Roy knew better than to question anything; he sat quietly in his grandfather’s truck as they rumbled down the big hill from their village, Hågat, to Big Navy, as the U.S. Naval Base in Guam is known. They passed through the military gates, along a dirt road and onto the shore of a little cove, next to one of America’s deepest harbors, where skipjacks flipped out of the aquamarine water. The boy noodled with seashells as his grandfather cast. When his grandfather caught a fish, he would unhook it and throw it on the ground, and Roy would snatch it up and quickly stuff it, still wriggling, in the bag. If the fish weren’t biting at one spot, they packed up and moved to another. No one from the Navy ever stopped the old man and the young boy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bayan Abubakr
title: Sudan Will Not Be Left for Dead
description: The world has failed Sudan. This isn’t the first time.
content: Before the war, I’d only ever gotten on my knees and begged in order to pray. This changed when I found myself pleading to escape the annihilation swallowing my country whole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Zelensky will discuss the grain deal with Turkey’s president, with a NATO bid in mind, too.
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is wrapping up an intense week of diplomacy with a visit to Istanbul on Friday to meet with Turkey’s president about the Black Sea grain deal that is once again facing an uncertain future, according to Turkey’s state-run Anadolu news agency.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is wrapping up an intense week of diplomacy with a visit to Istanbul on Friday to meet with Turkey’s president about the Black Sea grain deal that is once again facing an uncertain future, according to Turkey’s state-run Anadolu news agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Thanks, From Your Newsletter Anchor
description: Climate Forward’s lead writer is handing over the reins. She shared her parting thoughts.
content: Happy summer, friends. Today, I wrap up my turn at helming this newsletter. So, this is a thank-you card.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Children’s Books to Salvadoran Resistance
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: TRUFFLE: A Dog (and Cat) Story, by David McPhail. (Bugle Boy Press/Peter E. Randall, $18.95, ages 4 to 6.) When a farm dog inherits money in this charming watercolor-and-ink picture book, he retires from his (literal) rat race of a barnyard job to become a “gentleman of leisure” and go “where there are no cats!” Then he meets a feline in distress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Yan Mingfu, Who Tried to Defuse the Tiananmen Powder Keg, Dies at 91
description: As an envoy the to the pro-democracy protesters, Mr. Yan, who was also Mao’s interpreter, tried to find a peaceful way out of the crisis.
content: Yan Mingfu, the son of a Chinese Communist Party spy who became Mao Zedong’s interpreter and a negotiator who sought to defuse the standoff between the party and student protesters occupying Tiananmen Square in 1989, died on Monday in Beijing. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Taylor Swift’s Revised ‘Revenge,’ and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Prince, Rauw Alejandro, First Aid Kit and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: How Do ‘Barbie’ and Blackpink Figure in a Dangerous Territorial Dispute?
description: Vietnam banned the film over its apparent use of a Chinese map showing disputed territory. Blackpink concerts may be next. Here’s what the fuss is about.
content: Of all the things that could inflame tensions in a region that could someday be a theater of war between superpowers, the movie “Barbie” was not an obvious catalyst. Yet here we are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Canadian Court Rules 👍 Emoji Counts as a Contract Agreement
description: The ruling pointed to what a judge called the “new reality in Canadian society” that courts would have to confront as more people express themselves with thumbs, hearts and smiley faces.
content: Be careful before you casually dash off another thumbs-up emoji: A Canadian court has found that the ubiquitous symbol can affirm that a person is officially entering into a contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California Leaders Seek Federal Inquiry of Florida for Migrants Trips
description: In a letter to the Justice Department, Gov. Gavin Newsom, the California attorney general and a Texas sheriff said the Florida-funded program was based on deception.
content: Democratic leaders in California and Texas urged the Justice Department on Thursday to investigate a Florida program that has solicited asylum seekers in Texas and sent them with no apparent notice to Martha’s Vineyard and Sacramento.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 5: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by July 14 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 25.
content: Welcome to Week Five of our 14th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Rochelle Walensky on the Rocky Road to Normal
description: The former C.D.C. director looks back on how we got here.
content: Dr. Rochelle Walensky became the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention at what was both the darkest period of the pandemic and a moment of remarkable optimism. In early 2021, several thousand Americans were dying each day in Covid’s first, brutal winter surge. But vaccines were already being delivered, faster than in nearly any other country, and the inauguration of Joe Biden, who had campaigned in part on Donald Trump’s mishandling of the pandemic, promised a science-forward public-health reset.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: 120-Degree Heat Bakes and Broils the ‘City of Sun’
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 7, 2023.
content: “It was like I was being thrown balls of fire.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker
title: ‘Wherever I Am, I Am Always Birding’
description: The field-guide illustrator David Sibley says that drawing birds over a lifetime has shaped his entire way of seeing.
content: This week, for the New York Times summer birding project, we invite birders of all experience levels to try their hand at drawing a bird. You can do this from life or from a photograph. Try to produce at least one sketch in the upcoming week using any medium you wish. Share it with us by emailing birds@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Modern Farmhouse Is Today’s McMansion. And It’s Here to Stay.
description: In a divided country, a clean look and a neutral color palette is the aesthetic comforting communities around the country.
content: Drive through any American suburb and odds are you’ll spot a modern farmhouse in its natural habitat. The style is hard to miss: white board and batten vertical siding, large black frame windows, and gables. A covered porch, with a swing or maybe Adirondack chairs. A tin roof. And of course, house numbers in sans serif font.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauntel Lowe
title: Miles Bridges Will Rejoin Hornets After Felony Domestic Violence Plea Deal
description: Bridges will rejoin the team on a one-year contract after completing a suspension that will sideline him for the first 10 games of the season.
content: Miles Bridges will return to the Charlotte Hornets on a one-year contract next season after he finishes a suspension for pleading no contest to felony domestic violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Eric Schmitt
title: Biden Defends ‘Difficult’ Decision to Send Cluster Munitions to Ukraine
description: With Ukraine burning through stockpiles of conventional artillery, President Biden concluded that he had little choice but to provide the weapons.
content: President Biden defended his decision on Friday to provide Ukraine with cluster munitions, which are outlawed by many of America’s closest allies, saying it was a difficult decision but “the Ukrainians are running out of ammunition” in the fight against Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The End of the ‘Great Resignation,’ and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: The Heat Is Likely to Get Worse Next Week
description: Forecasters say dangerous heat is expected to return across the South. It could last another two weeks, and possibly longer.
content: It’s back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren LeBlanc
title: A Tragic Act of Gun Violence Repeats Itself in a Small Southern Town
description: In Amy Rowland’s second novel, “Inside the Wolf,” a New York City academic returns to her North Carolina roots to reconcile with old ghosts.
content: A cycle of “history, suffering, shame, again” rattles through “Inside the Wolf,” Amy Rowland’s wrenching sophomore novel, set in Shiloh, N.C. Awash with grief, Rachel Ruskin, 42 years old and recently denied tenure at a university in New York City, returns to her rural hometown where “everything except beer and mail requires a trip to Greenvale 20 miles away.” Her older brother, Garland, died by a self-inflicted gunshot a year ago, and after that her parents died together in a car accident. Rowland begins her novel at a crossroads fraught with regret and loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A weighty decision on contentious weapons for Ukraine.
content: After more than six months of deliberation, President Biden appeared on the verge of agreeing to ship cluster munitions to Ukraine. These are widely banned weapons known to cause grievous injury to civilians, and the step would sharply separate the U.S. from allies like Britain, Germany and France who have signed a treaty banning their use, stockpiling or transfer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Celebrates a Singer Who United East and West
description: A show at the German Historical Museum honors Wolf Biermann, whose music and moral stance endeared him to audiences across the once divided country.
content: If passers-by on a busy bridge in central Berlin on a recent summer afternoon recognized East Germany’s most famous songwriter, poet and dissident, they did not show it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Keith Bradsher
title: Yellen, in Beijing, Criticizes China’s Treatment of U.S. Companies
description: The concerns of Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen reflect continuing tensions between the two countries.
content: Of all the economic rifts between the United States and China, one felt personally by American executives is what they describe as the difficult, even hostile, conditions they face doing business in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Should a Notorious Crime Scene Be Demolished Before Trial?
description: Officials want to tear down the house where four Idaho college students were murdered last year, setting off a debate over preserving the scenes of mass violence.
content: At the house where four University of Idaho students were murdered last year, sheets of plywood cover the windows. A temporary fence surrounds the yard. Security guards, posted in a blue trailer, keep watch 24 hours a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Lauren Hirsch
title: Twitter Sues Law Firm Over $90 Million Payment in Elon Musk Deal
description: The lawsuit targeted Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, a well-known Wall Street law firm, for “unjust enrichment” related to Mr. Musk’s $44 billion purchase of Twitter.
content: Twitter’s parent company sued a leading corporate law firm on Friday for what it said were unjust payments related to Elon Musk’s $44 billion acquisition of the social media company last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Endicott
title: Kissing a Fellow Janitor Amid the Trash
description: After two assaults, I sought healing on the coldest, driest and windiest continent on Earth.
content: On my first day of work in Antarctica, I found a vibrator. I had been sorting through a skua cabinet, a freebie bin named after the seabirds that harassed us, demanding snacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Track Around a Park
description: Adrian Johnson opens our solving weekend with his first published themeless puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The I.R.A. Passed a Year Ago. Here’s a Progress Check.
description: Robinson Meyer offers a progress check on the Inflation Reduction Act and America’s path toward lower emissions.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows, which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the New York Times Audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cynthia Greenlee
title: How Do You Spell Discrimination?
description: MacNolia Cox speaks only one sentence in a picture book about her trip to the 1936 national spelling bee. Zaila Avant-garde, the 2021 champ, writes volumes.
content: In 1936, the eighth grader MacNolia Cox became the first Black student to win the Akron, Ohio, citywide spelling bee. Buoyed by community support, Cox traveled on a segregated train to Washington, D.C., and entered the arena for the national competition through a back door. When she reached the final five, the judges committed an act of racial perfidy. The word they gave her — nemesis — was not on the approved list. Cox spelled it N-E-M-A-S-I-S and was eliminated. The terrible prospect of Black excellence besting Anglo-Saxon smarts was narrowly avoided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why a Strong Jobs Report Could Rattle the Markets
description: Economists have forecast that employers created 225,000 jobs last month. A bigger-than-expected number could complicate the Federal Reserve’s efforts to tame inflation.
content: Economists and market participants are deeply divided about Friday’s payrolls report — due out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern — and what it may signal for the Fed’s interest rate policy and the chances of a recession this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: Patrick Wilson: The Scream King Takes the Director’s Chair
description: The actor had long wanted to make a film. When he was offered the job on the new “Insidious,” the chance to direct a box office hit proved very appealing.
content: When Patrick Wilson was first approached about reprising the role of Josh Lambert — the patriarch of a family terrorized by ghouls in James Wan’s haunted-house chiller, “Insidious” (2010) — he was unenthusiastic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Evva Hanes, Who Made Moravian Cookies World Famous, Dies at 90
description: She made several varieties of the thin, crispy cookie in a factory next door to her North Carolina home, and sold 10 million of them a year.
content: Evva Hanes, a North Carolina farm woman who took a centuries-old Moravian cookie tradition that she had learned by watching her mother bake on a wood-fired stove and turned it into a family business, one that now ships out millions of fragile, crispy Moravian cookies every year, died on June 22 at her home in Clemmons, N.C. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The Contentious U.S.-China Relationship, by the Numbers
description: From movie theaters to military spending, here’s how one of the world’s most important economic relationships stacks up.
content: China and the United States are locked in an increasingly intense rivalry when it comes to national security and economic competition, with American leaders frequently identifying China as their greatest long-term challenger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Sue Johanson, Who Talked Sex With Aplomb, Dies at 92
description: A beloved radio and television host, first in Canada and then also in the U.S., she approached the hottest topic with compassion and humor.
content: Sue Johanson, the blunt, bawdy and beloved Canadian sex educator and host of the long-running television call-in program “Sunday Night Sex Show” and its American counterpart, “Talk Sex With Sue Johanson,” died on June 28 at a care facility in North Toronto. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Paige McClanahan
title: What It’s Like to be a Female Tour Guide in Saudi Arabia
description: Fatimah Al Zimam has introduced visitors from around the world to her country, which opened to nonreligious tourism in 2019. She discusses her favorite sites, driving a pickup truck and how her country is changing.
content: Fatimah Al Zimam likes to walk around in black leggings and casual tops, and she wears her curly hair loose and uncovered. She owns a silver GMC pickup truck, which she loves to take on solo drives across the Saudi desert. And she is passionate about her work: As a tour guide, she has introduced her country to visitors from the United States, France, Britain, Italy, China and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: 5 National Park Destinations That Aren’t Parks
description: The National Park Service isn’t just the 63 big-name parks. Here are national monuments, a lakeshore and two other less crowded alternatives to explore the country’s natural beauty and attractions.
content: Many of the 63 national parks across the United States have seen an explosion of visitor numbers both during and after the pandemic, which often has led to booked campsites, clogged trails and timed entry requirements in an attempt to limit crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Fleischaker
title: Corn and Coconut Soup, But Make It Lazy
description: It’s hot, and it’s vacation season. Here are some clever summer recipe shortcuts that save time and energy.
content: Hi! This is a different Emily (Fleischaker) than usual. I’m a deputy editor on the food and cooking desk, filling in for Emily Weinstein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, William K. Rashbaum and Susan C. Beachy
title: Six Charged With Organizing Illegal Donations to Adams’s 2021 Campaign
description: One defendant knew Mayor Eric Adams when they were police officers. Prosecutors did not accuse the mayor of knowing about what they called a scheme to acquire thousands of dollars in extra public matching funds.
content: A retired inspector who worked and socialized with Mayor Eric Adams when they were both members of the New York Police Department was charged on Friday with conspiring with four construction executives and a bookkeeper to funnel illegal donations to Mr. Adams’s 2021 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Cottage Cheese Makes a Comeback
description: The diet staple of the ’70s is jiggling back into the mainstream — bringing with it a host of health benefits.
content: Some devour it plain, spooned straight from the tub. Others smear it over toast like burrata; blend it with sweet ingredients to make healthier versions of ice cream or cookie dough; or use it as a dip (paired with mustard) for raw veggies, fruits, sausages and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: M.L.B. Draft Trades Magic for Efficiency
description: The days of unlimited picks are over, and while the league says the opportunities are still there, previous late-round picks aren’t so sure.
content: On Sunday in Seattle, for the fourth year in a row — enough for a full class of college prospects — Major League Baseball will hold a streamlined version of its amateur draft. From an event with unlimited rounds to one with 50 rounds, then 40, and now just 20, the draft is exclusive and efficient, in keeping with baseball’s restructured minor league system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Donors Are War-Weary, So Ukrainian Soldiers Get Creative for Funds
description: A robust fund-raising operation has been critical in supplying Ukraine’s military. But as the war drags on, contributions have lagged.
content: Under the vaulted brick arches of a contemporary art center in central Kyiv, a soldier in military green gave a reading of his own poetry, far from the front lines of the war he has been fighting since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Democrats Denounce Biden’s Decision to Send Cluster Munitions to Ukraine
description: Some lawmakers questioned how the United States could maintain the moral high ground while supplying Ukraine with weapons that could harm civilians. Republicans cheered the move.
content: President Biden’s decision to send cluster munitions to Ukraine has angered a wide range of Democrats, who are accusing his administration of making a hypocritical decision that risked the moral standing of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and J. Edward Moreno
title: Looming UPS Strike Spurs Some Companies to Rethink Supply Chains
description: Businesses around the country are facing what could be the latest disruption to how they get their goods to their customers in a timely and affordable fashion.
content: Kathryn Keeler and her husband, Stuart de Haaff, own an olive oil company in the hills of central California. The couple spend their days harvesting olives, bottling the oil, labeling the glass bottles and shipping them out, relying primarily on UPS to get their product to kitchens throughout the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Giuliani Should Lose His Law License in D.C., Bar Panel Says
description: The recommendation for disbarment of Rudolph W. Giuliani followed a hearing where evidence was presented that he had improperly sought to help Donald J. Trump overturn the results of the 2020 election.
content: A legal ethics committee in Washington that oversaw a disciplinary case late year against Rudolph W. Giuliani recommended on Friday that he be disbarred for his “unparalleled” attempts to overturn the 2020 election in favor of his client at the time, President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Overlooked No More: Hannie Schaft, Resistance Fighter During World War II
description: She killed Nazis in the Netherlands and was known as “the girl with the red hair” on their most-wanted list. Then she was executed.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kia Corthron
title: The Pains and Struggles of Family in Three Debut Novels
description: Complicated families abound in new books by Nathan Go, Lucian Childs and Elysha Chang.
content: Early in Nathan Go’s debut novel, FORGIVING IMELDA MARCOS (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 226 pp., $26), Lito, the story’s dying protagonist, prepares his circuitous yarn by asserting “the best way to fit one story among other stories is, I think, always wise to consider.” And it is indeed with wisdom and dexterity that Go intertwines the stories of three periods of Lito’s life: his final months, when Lito writes letters to his estranged son from a nursing home (which is the foundation of the novel); his youth, recounted via the memories that Lito has elected to share; and an extraordinary midlife occasion when, as a driver for the former Philippines revolutionary president Corazon Aquino, Lito is directed to transport the country’s leader to the home of Imelda Marcos, the scandalous widow of Ferdinand Marcos, Aquino’s predecessor and political rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Court Denies Indian Opposition Leader’s Petition to Suspend Conviction
description: The defamation case, stemming from a comment Rahul Gandhi made about Prime Minister Narendra Modi, could go to the Supreme Court. It may hurt his ability to run in upcoming elections.
content: Rahul Gandhi, India’s top opposition leader, faced another setback on Friday when a court in the state of Gujarat denied his request to stay his conviction in a defamation case, a move that leaves him at risk of imprisonment and possibly unable to run in national elections next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Erin Nolan
title: As Fatal Ship Fire Burns On, a New Challenge: Keep It From Capsizing
description: As water is sprayed on a burning cargo ship in Port Newark, N.J., it must also be released to avoid sinking the vessel, which is carrying 1,200 cars.
content: As a fatal fire continued to burn aboard a cargo ship at Port Newark in New Jersey, emergency workers on Friday scrambled to extinguish the blaze while working to prevent an environmental disaster in the most populated region of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 7, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 7, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about a suit filed by four countries over an Iranian missile that hit a Ukraine Airlines passenger flight misstated the year that the U.N. rapporteur, Agnes Callamard, published her report about the downing of the flight. It was in 2021, not 2001.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
title: They Fell in Love in a Video Game. Now Both Are in Jail.
description: The barrier-breaking romance of a Pakistani woman and an Indian man has led to criminal charges and nationalist intrigue.
content: Their love affair across one of the world’s most heavily guarded borders had begun on the virtual battlefields of a video game where players bond over having one another’s back against bloody enemy ambushes to become the last survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: In Her First Term, Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson ‘Came to Play’
description: The first Black female member of the Supreme Court wasted no time in finding her footing, asserting herself in dissents, alliances and questions from the bench.
content: From her first week on the Supreme Court bench in October to the final day of the term that ended last week, Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson did something remarkable for a junior justice: She established herself as a distinctive voice on the court.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Robinson Meyer
description: The July 7, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Robinson Meyer. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: L.S.U. Teammates Are Unprecedented 1-2 Punch in M.L.B. Draft
description: In a draft loaded with talent, Paul Skenes and Dylan Crews could be the first teammates to be taken with the top two picks.
content: The top pick in this year’s Major League Baseball draft will probably come from Louisiana State’s College World Series-winning team. The only question seems to be which player will head to the Pittsburgh Pirates at No. 1, and which will go to the Washington Nationals at No. 2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Hawthorne
title: This Time, Herzog & de Meuron Are Inside the Museum
description: The architects behind museums in San Francisco, Miami and Minneapolis, and the Powerhouse Arts Complex, in Brooklyn, are the subjects of a major exhibition, in London.
content: In its early years, the architecture firm that Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron founded in 1978 in Basel, Switzerland, was known for buildings that expressed personality through their exterior skins. Each design became a kind of essay on the architectural possibilities of a single material. There were the fiber-cement panels of the 1987 Ricola storage facility in Laufen, Switzerland, and the gabion walls, filled with stones, of the Dominus winery in the Napa Valley, completed a decade later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A Second Chance at Love and Blended Families
description: Michelle Evans and Eric Koch did not think second marriages were in their future — until a mutual friend urged them to connect.
content: The Brady Bunch have nothing on Michelle Lynn Evans and Eric Randolph Koch: Between the two of them, they have eight children and 48 years of marriage with former partners. While Ms. Evans had no intention of marrying again, and Dr. Koch remained ambivalent as well, Facebook and a mutual friend, Susan Ramos, changed all that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom and Jillian Weinberger
title: The Supreme Court Shattered the American Dream
description: Tressie McMillan Cottom on the justices’ rejection of affirmative action and student debt cancellation.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows, which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: De-Dollarization Debunked
description: Why the greenback’s dominance remains durable.
content: The U.S. dollar is, in a real sense, the money of moneys — that is, in many ways it is to other national currencies what money in general is to other goods and assets. Most of us rarely engage in barter; we sell stuff for dollars, then use those dollars to buy other stuff. Similarly, a large share of international transactions, especially in financial markets, involves payments in dollars rather than in local currencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a sweet dragon tale, the new “Avatar” installment and an updated Cinderella story.
content: “My Father’s Dragon,” an adaptation of the 1948 children’s novel of the same name by Ruth Stiles Gannett, follows a young boy named Elmer (Jacob Tremblay, recently the voice of Flounder in “The Little Mermaid”) who is living a blissful life with his mother, Dela (Golshifteh Farahani). When Dela’s business shuts down, it forces her to move to a city tenement and scramble for work. A black cat (voiced by Whoopi Goldberg) tells Elmer to journey to a place called Wild Island and free a dragon named Boris, who can, in turn, bring fame and fortune to Dela. Elmer finds Boris (Gaten Matarazzo of “Stranger Things”) and what ensues is a tender story of friendship, fear and bravery. Beautiful hand-drawn animation and wide-eyed characters are a signature of Cartoon Saloon, the Oscar-nominated Irish animation studio that produced this film along with Netflix and Mockingbird Pictures. And thanks to the director Nora Twomey (“The Breadwinner”) and the screenwriter Meg LeFauve (“Inside Out”), both Oscar nominees, this 2022 film’s sweet, important lessons — that it’s OK to be scared sometimes and that bonds between friends give us courage — are made digestible for young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Andy Murray’s Run at Wimbledon Is Short and Bittersweet
description: In a punishing second-round match played over two days, Stefanos Tsitsipas outlasted Wimbledon’s favorite son over five sets.
content: Streams of glum British tennis fans filed quietly out of Centre Court on Friday, moments after their Scottish hero had himself departed with a quick two-handed wave before disappearing from their sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Clare Toeniskoetter, Will Reid, Mary Wilson, Devon Taylor, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: The Complicated Future of Student Loans
description: The dismissal of a plan to wipe out more than $400 billion in student debt has dashed the hopes of tens of millions of borrowers.
content: Last week, the Supreme Court struck down President Biden’s sweeping plan to cancel billions of dollars in student loan debt.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Use A.I. for Family Time
description: Plan meals, find gifts and create stories using generative A.I.
content: Hello! We’re back with another bonus edition of On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that teaches you about artificial intelligence, how it works and how to use it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: She Drew the Line at Marriage, Then Happily Crossed It.
description: When her first marriage ended badly, Brooke Rinehart swore never to marry again. Then she met Tom Sinnott. The two developed a special closeness and agreed to start a family together.
content: On a hike during a vacation on the Hawaiian island of Kauai, Heather Brooke Rinehart was one month pregnant and needed to stop for a snack at a beach. As she rested, she noticed that someone had written “Will You Marry Me?” in the sand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: How Elba Makes a Living Wage
description: We’re covering a hotel strike in Los Angeles, extreme heat and an Alzheimer’s drug.
content: Early in Barack Obama’s recent Netflix documentary series about American jobs, viewers meet a housekeeper at the Pierre Hotel in New York named Elba. She spends her shifts cleaning hotel rooms, and she talks about the job’s challenges, including back pain and guests’ occasional misbehavior. Elba is meant to be a symbol of difficult service-industry work in today’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: The TikTok Algorithm That Brought Them Together
description: Kelly Winget fell asleep 20 minutes after knocking on Sarah Matteson’s front door for a first date. “It felt so natural to walk in there, and talk to each other a little and then just go to bed,” Ms. Winget said.
content: Growing up in Dallas, Kelly Ann Winget’s parents used to remind her that her lifestyle was not the norm, but being gay in a conservative state like Texas= had nothing to do with it. Instead, Ms. Winget, who described herself as the daughter of a fifth-generation oil and gas family, said they were “very well-to-do.” But her parents still “wanted us to be exposed to the real world — if we wanted something, we had to work for it,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: Penn Station Is a Perpetual Mess. Change May Be at Hand.
description: There may finally be hope for New York’s busiest, dreariest train hub, with a new plan to improve it, the stars aligning and the clock ticking.
content: If the latest flurry of news around two dueling plans to fix New York’s Pennsylvania Station has left you scratching your head, you’re not alone. Various officials I have spoken with are also fuzzy on details.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Is the Threads Logo Supposed to Look Like?
description: Sure, it’s probably an @ symbol. But the abstract logo of Instagram’s new Twitter rival has drawn comparisons to an ear, an ampersand and a piece of spaghetti.
content: There’s a hot new squiggle on the tech logo scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: After a Hurricane, Presenting a Rainbow Fabric Ring
description: Molly Gaebe proposed to Leila Bozorg with a rainbow fabric ring and the help of the couple’s favorite drag queen.
content: Nothing could stop Molly Beth Gaebe from attending her former college softball teammate’s wedding in Stonington, Conn. Not even knee surgery. “You can’t go,” she recalled her friends saying, to which she replied, “Just watch me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Special Counsel Inquiries Into Trump Cost at Least $5.4 Million
description: The Justice Department also disclosed $616,000 in spending by the special counsel scrutinizing President Biden’s handling of classified files.
content: The investigations into former President Donald J. Trump’s hoarding of government files and his efforts to overturn the 2020 election cost taxpayers about $5.4 million from November through March as the special counsel, Jack Smith, moved toward charging Mr. Trump, the Justice Department disclosed on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Record a Win Every Day — and Other Ways to Practice Gratitude
description: Nearly 800 readers shared some of their favorite tips.
content: Jancee Dunn is out this week. I’m Christina Caron, a reporter on the Well desk, filling in.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Power of Community, Religious and Secular
description: Readers respond to an essay by Rabbi David Wolpe. Also: The immorality of cluster munitions; abortion stories; comparing Canada and the U.S.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Kevin Draper
title: Embattled PGA Tour Leader Expected to Return This Month
description: Jay Monahan went on medical leave in June, days after he announced plans for the tour’s alliance with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund.
content: Jay Monahan, the PGA Tour commissioner, who went on medical leave last month as he and his organization faced outrage over a planned alliance with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, is expected to return to his position on July 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob E. Gersen
title: If We Are What We Eat, We Don’t Know Who We Are
description: In “Ultra-Processed People,” Chris van Tulleken takes a close look at the franken-snacks that barely resemble what they’re imitating.
content: Today, Sylvester Graham is best known for the cracker that bears his name. But in his heyday, Graham was an influential writer and lecturer on wholesome living. The term “mobbed” was apparently coined to describe what often happened when he spoke; having advocated for chastity in marriage and home cooking, he literally got chased out of town by husbands and bakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shamus Khan
title: Legacy Admissions Don’t Work the Way You Think They Do
description: They are part of the reason less advantaged students get so much out of elite schools.
content: Just four days after the Supreme Court rejected racial preferences in college admissions, a consortium of Black and Latino interest groups filed a complaint against Harvard concerning a different kind of preference: the special consideration given to the children of alumni. The filing notes that the practice of legacy admissions disproportionately benefits white applicants. If racial considerations are to be strictly limited, the plaintiffs argue, other considerations that effectively favor some racial groups must also go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
title: No Wagner Group Here: Riddles Grow as Belarus Displays an Empty Base
description: Two weeks after the Wagner mercenary group’s rebellion against Russian military leadership, its fate is as murky as ever — as is the purpose of a newly revived military base in Belarus.
content: Off the highway, past an evergreen forest and behind a rusty gate, hundreds of recently erected tents, stuffed with bunk beds made from slabs of fragrant pine wood, stand ready for use in central Belarus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Christine Hauser
title: Abraham Lincoln Letter From Early Civil War Era Sells for $85,000
description: The short, unpublished letter had been in the same private collection for at least a century before it was acquired by the Raab Collection in Pennsylvania earlier this year.
content: A recently discovered letter written by President Abraham Lincoln that offers a glimpse into his thinking during the early part of the Civil War sold this week in Pennsylvania for $85,000, according to an autograph dealer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Christopher F. Schuetze, Aurelien Breeden and Katie Rogers
title: Cluster munitions are a question for individual countries, NATO’s secretary general says.
description: American allies reacted with caution on Friday to reports that the Biden administration said it would provide Ukraine with cluster munitions, widely banned weapons that often cause grievous injury to civilians, especially children.
content: American allies reacted with caution on Friday to reports that the Biden administration said it would provide Ukraine with cluster munitions, widely banned weapons that often cause grievous injury to civilians, especially children.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Revisiting ‘Bridget Jones’s Diary’ Plus the Art of Literary Translation
description: Elisabeth Egan and Tina Jordan talk about Helen Fielding’s novel, and Gregory Cowles and Juliana Barbassa discuss all things translation.
content: On this week’s episode of the podcast, Gilbert Cruz talks to Juliana Barbassa and Gregory Cowles about the Book Review’s special translation issue, and to Tina Jordan and Elisabeth Egan about the novel “Bridget Jones’s Diary,” which was published in the U.S. 25 years ago this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Threads: An Early Vibe Check
description: It’s early days, but more than 30 million users have signed up.
content: Hi, everyone. Madison is out this week, so I’ve hacked the mainframe and seized control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a hiking trip gone wrong and a luxury vacation that takes a depraved turn.
content: Dan Berk and Robert Olsen’s film starts with a mysterious red flare streaking down from the sky, so right away we suspect who (or what) will trigger the plot. And it might not be friendly, because the odds of a backpacking trip going right in a sci-fi movie are fairly low. Indeed, things quickly go awry after Harry (Jake Lacy, from Season 1 of “The White Lotus”) and his girlfriend, Ruth (Maika Monroe, “It Follows”), take off on an isolated Oregon trail. She is wracked by anxiety so crippling that she has been taking medication and seeing a therapist, but gamely tries to not spoil a trip Jake has carefully planned. And then, of course, it all goes to pot, with a couple of nifty red herrings and plot twists spicing up the script. “Significant Other” (the title cleverly plays off a couple of different meanings) is a tight, effective hybrid of science fiction and horror, with the scares generated less by shock tactics than by a growing dread. That anguish is generated in the viewer in part by good filmmaking — the movie is briskly paced, well acted and moodily atmospheric (only the C.G.I. looks a little cheap). And partly it derives from “Significant Other” dealing with common preoccupations: Do we ever fully know who we lie next to?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Joe Rennison
title: The June Payrolls Report Probably Doesn’t Change Much for the Fed
description: Federal Reserve officials are still expected to raise interest rates in July after a solid jobs report showed continued wage growth.
content: Federal Reserve policymakers are keenly focused on the strength of the labor market as they debate how much further the economy needs to cool to ensure that quick inflation fades back to a normal pace. Fresh labor market data released on Friday probably offered little to dissuade them from raising interest rates at their meeting this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Homeless World Cup Arrives in Sacramento
description: A remarkable soccer competition for people who have been homeless within the past two years aims to help them regain a sense of purpose.
content: California’s homelessness crisis is no secret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Gunman in El Paso Mass Shooting Sentenced for Federal Hate Crimes
description: The gunman had pleaded guilty to the charges in federal court. He still faces a state murder trial later this year, and Texas prosecutors said they would seek the death penalty.
content: A self-described white nationalist who wrote that Hispanics were “invading” America before fatally shooting 23 people at a Walmart store in El Paso was sentenced on Friday to 90 consecutive life terms for his conviction on federal hate crimes charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Britney Spears Seeks Apology After Encounter With Victor Wembanyama’s Security
description: Spears said on Twitter that a member of the athlete’s security detail had hit her outside a Las Vegas restaurant. The police said Friday that no charges would be filed.
content: The singer Britney Spears asked for an apology on Thursday after accusing a member of a star N.B.A. player’s security detail of striking her in the face outside a Las Vegas restaurant when she tried to greet the player, Victor Wembanyama of the San Antonio Spurs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick A. Martínez
title: For the Best Tortillas (and Gorditas and Tetelas), You Need Fresh Masa
description: This cornerstone of Mexican cuisine infuses so many dishes with depth and verve.
content: A freshly ground masa tortilla, as it cooks on a comal, inflates as the steam inside pushes apart the sides and releases an intoxicating toasted corn aroma. It actually tastes like nutty, earthy corn, with a soft, chewy texture and almost custardy center. And its role is not just to transport a taco filling and salsas from your plate to your mouth, but to complement and ground the bright, acidic and spicy flavors with something rich and soothing, familiar and homey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: In Ag-Friendly Iowa, Trump Goes After DeSantis on Farming Issues
description: At a rally in Iowa on Friday, the former president questioned his top Republican rival’s support for the agriculture industry.
content: Donald J. Trump attacked Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Friday over his support for farmers, saying his chief rival for the Republican presidential nomination would be “a catastrophe” for the country’s agriculture industry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Just Like a Woman: Female Artists Cover Bob Dylan
description: Hear versions by Marianne Faithfull, Joan Baez, Nina Simone and more.
content: In 2016, when Bob Dylan became the first singer-songwriter to receive the Nobel Prize for Literature, The Guardian asked six female artists to talk about his work. With his wild, Einsteinian coif, Romantic poet adoration and cryptic, sometimes ornery nature, Dylan is often held up as an emblematic example of the modern male genius. We’ve heard plenty about him from men over the years; refreshingly, The Guardian let some brilliant and fascinating women have their turn. “My mother always thought that Dylan was somewhat misogynistic,” the singer-songwriter Suzanne Vega said, “but I don’t see that. I see a whole range of female characters in his music from goddesses and queens and women revered and then also women used, abused.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Creator of ‘The Wire’ Asks Mercy for Man Charged in Actor’s Death
description: David Simon said the man, who was part of a crew that sold Michael K. Williams the fentanyl that killed him, deserves leniency as a victim of addiction himself.
content: The 2021 overdose of the actor Michael K. Williams, famous for playing a drug-world gunman, stands out as an example of fentanyl’s deadly march. Now, as one man charged in connection with his death faces sentencing, one of Mr. Williams’s closest friends wants the case to stand for something else: mercy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: The 50 Best Movies on Netflix Right Now
description: Movies upon movies await, and you don’t even have to drill down to find them.
content: Sign up for our Watching newsletter to get recommendations on the best films and TV shows to stream and watch, delivered to your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Pepperoncini Tuna Salad, Stuffed Into a Split Croissant
description: Or maybe you’d like a turkey sandwich with savory blueberry jam, a fried eggplant hero or sliced radishes in a baguette with butter and salt.
content: Good morning. Here’s an excellent sandwich I ate around 60 miles south of the Jones Inlet on Long Island the other day, zooming around the New York Bight looking for offshore bluefin tuna: mortadella, provolone and napa cabbage kimchi on a buttered baguette, with pickled jalapeños and cilantro leaves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: This French Open Champion Nearly Gave Up Tennis to Sell Insurance
description: After years of frustration in singles, Austin Krajicek nearly quit tennis. Then an old friend asked him if he wanted to give the sport one more shot.
content: The last time Austin Krajicek stormed through the front door, threw his tennis bag into a closet and announced that he was done with the sport for good, his wife, Misia Kedzierski, thought he might actually be serious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fu
title: China Fines Ant Group $985 Million, in Sign Crackdown Is Over
description: After nearly three years of regulatory scrutiny, the fine is seen as a sign that Beijing is wrapping up its crackdown on technology firms.
content: The Chinese authorities announced a fine of nearly $1 billion for the financial technology firm Ant Group on Friday, nearly three years after regulators halted the company’s plan for a record-breaking public offering that ushered in a period of intense government scrutiny of technology firms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Ryan
title: Antibiotic Shortage Could Worsen Syphilis Epidemic
description: The primary drug used to treat the sexually transmitted infection could be scarce into next year, Pfizer warns.
content: A new shortage of a type of penicillin crucial to the fight against syphilis is alarming infectious disease experts, who warn that a protracted scarcity of the drug could worsen the U.S. epidemic of the sexually transmitted infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: India Arrests 3 Railway Workers in Train Crash That Killed 290
description: The workers were detained on charges that included endangering the safety of passengers and tampering with evidence, the Central Bureau of Investigation said.
content: Indian officials on Friday arrested three railway workers in connection with a deadly train crash last month that left at least 290 people dead and once again highlighted safety problems across a vast train network that serves as an important lifeline for the poor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek and Ben Hubbard
title: Palestinians, Facing Political Stagnation, Despair After Israeli Raid
description: In the occupied West Bank, Palestinians say they feel betrayed by their leaders, forgotten by world powers and unable to protect themselves or their property from attacks by Israelis.
content: When he learned that the Israeli army had launched a raid this week to comb for weapons and explosives in the occupied West Bank city of Jenin, Mahmoud Sarahat and his friends mobilized to fight back. His comrades shot at Israeli soldiers, while he helped evacuate the wounded and the dead, he said, retrieving their guns to give to other fighters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson, Edward Wong and Olivia Wang
title: U.S. Raises Pressure on China to Combat Global Fentanyl Crisis
description: The Biden administration push comes after cooperation on halting the flow of the drug into the United States was derailed by wider geopolitical tensions.
content: Just four years ago, a joint American and Chinese effort to stem the flow of fentanyl produced in China from reaching the United States appeared set to take off. Beijing had unveiled a sweeping new law banning the synthetic opioid, leading the Trump administration to praise China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, for “a wonderful humanitarian gesture.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Dan Bilefsky
title: Dutch Government Collapses Over Plan to Further Limit Immigration
description: Prime Minister Mark Rutte, one of Europe’s longest-serving leaders, had struggled to reach an agreement with his coalition partners about migration, including more restrictions.
content: The Dutch government collapsed on Friday after the parties in its ruling coalition failed to reach an agreement on migration policy, underlining how the issue of asylum seekers coming to Europe continues to divide governments across the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Wisconsin Judge Allows Challenge to Abortion Law to Proceed
description: The preliminary ruling on the law, passed long before Roe v. Wade, gave hope to abortion-rights supporters who want to restore access to the procedure.
content: Abortion-rights supporters in Wisconsin secured an incremental but important legal victory on Friday when a judge allowed a lawsuit seeking to restore abortion access in the state to proceed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Look at the Stocks Leading the Market Now
description: Devastated at the height of the pandemic, cruise lines have become top performers.
content: Many top performers in the stock market for the first half of this year were exactly what you would expect, if you’ve been following the news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Fire Breaks Out at Milan Retirement Home, Killing at Least 6
description: The cause of the blaze, which also sent dozens of people to the hospital, was under investigation. “It could have been much worse,” said the city’s mayor.
content: Six people died and dozens more were hospitalized for smoke inhalation after a fire broke out overnight in a retirement home in Milan, the authorities said Friday, adding that the toll could have been far higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Why Backers Say a New Tunnel to Manhattan Benefits the Broader Economy
description: A $6.88 billion grant will mean more trains, more passengers, and a boost to the region’s economy.
content: The long-delayed project to build a train tunnel under the Hudson River to New York City received a big boost from the federal government this week, a $6.88 billion grant announced by Senator Chuck Schumer of New York on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Uncle Vanya’ Review: Confidences by Candlelight
description: Unrequited love swirls through this prestige-cast production of Anton Chekhov’s play, in a Manhattan loft.
content: Leaning close in the flickering candlelight, Sonya and the man who makes her stomach flutter share a sneaky midnight snack. He is Astrov, her houseguest, and he is frankly a bit of a mess — drinks too much, is in fact drunk at the moment. He is also endearingly odd and smart and sweet, an eco-nerd physician who’s sending her some incredibly mixed signals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Tips for Canceling Online Subscriptions
description: It’s easy to sign up but not always so easy to stop a service. The F.T.C. is proposing rules to change that.
content: Online subscriptions of all kinds have been mushrooming in recent years. While signing up is easy, managing and cutting them back is difficult, even for savvy consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Ex-Army Finance Counselor Swindled Gold Star Families, U.S. Says
description: Instead of helping dead service members’ relatives collect life insurance and other benefits, Caz Craffy duped them while enriching himself, prosecutors said.
content: A former U.S. Army financial counselor used his position to bilk two dozen dead service members’ families out of life insurance and other benefits by steering them to investments on which he was secretly reaping hefty commissions, federal prosecutors said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Avoidable Mistake of a UPS Strike
description: The Teamsters and management have surprisingly strong ties.
content: Every intense relationship has frictions, and the one between the Teamsters union and United Parcel Service is no exception. Negotiations have broken down in the final stage of talks on a five-year contract, with the Teamsters vowing to strike if a new contract isn’t ratified by the time the current one expires on July 31. Each side has accused the other of walking away from the bargaining table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: In the Coldest Place on Earth, Trying to Outrun a Burden of Hurt
description: “Memories of the event came flooding back, my confidence crumbled, and I ran as far away as possible — to Antarctica.”
content: After being raped by two different men, Elizabeth Endicott struggled to maintain her sense of self.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: somber
description: This word has appeared in 225 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word somber has appeared in 225 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 5 in “In India, Trains Start Running Again by Devastating Crash Site” by Hari Kumar, Isabella Kwai and Sameer Yasir:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Against the Odds, the U.S. Economy Chugs Along, as Fears Linger
description: Hiring slowed last month, a sign that the Federal Reserve’s inflation-fighting campaign is taking hold. But with rising wages and low unemployment, the labor market remains resilient.
content: The U.S. labor market showed signs of continued cooling last month but extended a two-and-a-half-year streak of job growth, the Labor Department said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Ukraine Waits for a Tomorrow It Cannot See
description: Soccer is not a priority in Ukraine, nor should it be. But the country’s greatest player says it still has a vital role to play in his nation’s sense of itself.
content: There are certain things Andriy Shevchenko cannot talk about. The feeling generated by the wailing of an air-raid siren. The dread instilled by learning just how many missiles had been aimed the previous night at you, your loved ones, your home. The sensation of knowing another swarm of drones is on its way, the only hope that each one can be shot from the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Teen Arrested After Shooting in Baltimore Leaves 2 Dead and 28 Wounded
description: The police called the 17-year-old a “person of interest” in the shooting on Sunday and said he had been charged with possession of an assault weapon and other crimes.
content: A 17-year-old was arrested on Friday and charged with gun crimes as detectives investigate whether he was involved in a shooting on Sunday at a Baltimore block party that killed two people and wounded 28 others, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: An Uneasy Quiet at NATO’s Newest Border With Russia
description: Finland’s membership in the Western military alliance has increased NATO’s borders with Russia by 830 miles — and angered Moscow.
content: On a recent afternoon along Finland’s border with Russia, an attack from Russian military bases a few miles away seemed a distant prospect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: ‘Insidious: The Red Door’ Review: The Ghost of Jump Scares Past
description: Patrick Wilson makes his directorial debut with this fifth installment of the horror franchise haunted by a red-faced demon.
content: “Insidious,” whose fifth installment opened Friday, is a second-tier horror franchise — it’s not even the best James Wan franchise starring Patrick Wilson, which would be “The Conjuring” — with a few elite jump scares, including one of the best in the genre. In the original in 2010, Lorraine Lambert (Barbara Hershey) is telling her son, Josh (Wilson), about a horrible dream when a red-faced demon suddenly appears behind his head. It’s a magnificent shock because of the askew blocking, the patient misdirection of the editing and Hershey’s committed performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 11 Chicken Recipes You’ll Make All Summer Long
description: Grilled or baked, breast or thighs, here are ideas for turning chicken into an easy meal.
content: This and every summer, grill some chicken. With corn. With peaches. With tomatoes. With abandon! Or don’t: You can still evoke the flavors and smells of the season inside using the stovetop or the oven (or a store-bought rotisserie chicken, when it gets unbearably hot). Below is a sampling of some of the most flavorful summertime chicken recipes New York Times Cooking has to offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: How Would Harvard Talk About My Kids?
description: We are far more than six categories on a demographic form.
content: It’s rare that I find myself nodding along in agreement with the conservative members of the Supreme Court. But reading Chief Justice John Roberts’s majority opinion striking down affirmative action programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina, I all but turned into a bobblehead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Turning New York’s Stately Public Library Into a Place ‘to Hang Out In’
description: Behind the stone lions on Fifth Avenue, the New York Public Library’s imposing Fifth Avenue branch has added a new visitor center and an expanded gift shop and cafe.
content: The palatial Beaux-Arts library on Fifth Avenue guarded by a pair of stone lions was not where Farrah Denson wanted to be when she was a teenager growing up on the Upper West Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Job Market Cools, but Remains Strong
description: Also, the U.S. gives Ukraine cluster munitions. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: U.S. employers added 209,000 jobs in June, which was the 30th consecutive month of job growth, according to data released today. The gains, however, were the slowest in a two-and-a-half-year streak of growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Stone Shayer
title: American Ballet Theater Does Not See Me as I See Myself
description: There is no separating the Black dancer from the dance.
content: I am a ballet dancer and a Black man, in that order. I left the United States to train at the Bolshoi Ballet Academy in Moscow at age 15 so that people would see my skill first and not my skin. It was a naïve dream, I realize now, since unlike painters, whose work can be regarded without their presence, I am both the artist and the artwork, and there can be no separation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Good News, Florida. The Giant Seaweed Blob Has Shrunk.
description: The blob, known as the great Atlantic Sargassum belt, shrank in the Gulf of Mexico by 75 percent last month, scientists said.
content: For months, Florida’s usually picturesque coast was plagued by a rotting tangle of seaweed, known as sargassum. Then, as quickly as the stinking mass arrived, it began to disappear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: DeSantis Unleashes His Humanizer-in-Chief: His Wife
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s wife, Casey DeSantis, held her first solo campaign event in Iowa, connecting with fellow moms and casting her husband as a champion of the “parents’ rights” movement.
content: She was there to woo the conservative moms of Iowa. So Casey DeSantis, the wife of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, wasted no time in talking about her three young children — and how badly she wanted to leave them home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Boasts $20 Million Haul, but Full Picture of Money Race Is Still Hazy
description: The Florida governor had an impressive quarter, but the fund-raising numbers also raised questions about his ability to keep pace over the course of the Republican primary.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida raised $20 million in the first six weeks of his presidential run, his campaign said Thursday, a substantial sum that solidifies his place as the leading rival to former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Millions Danced Joyfully to Her Song. She Drew on Her Pain to Write It.
description: Nomcebo Zikode, the South African singer of the pandemic hit “Jerusalema” that inspired a global dance challenge, wrote the chorus while battling her own depression.
content: It starts with a clap, and then the feet tap along to the beat: four times on each side, followed by a quick jump. As the melody rises, dancers dip low and twirl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn and Tristan Spinski
title: How Mistaken Identity and One Bullet Revealed a Star Predator Far From Home
description: A hunter’s kill in upstate New York brought new hope, and trepidation, that wolves could slowly be making their way back to the Northeast.
content: The rustling in the brush was loud, so Brian Christman raised his muzzleloader for the deer he expected to emerge. It was the end of the season in central New York, and Mr. Christman was hoping to take home a buck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: What’s the Future of Wood-Fired Pizza in New York?
description: New regulations don’t mean the end of traditional pizza ovens. But they raise some issues for restaurants.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Last week the internet was concerned about the future of wood-fired pizza in New York City. We’ll take a look at the proposed rules that caused the uproar, talk to local pizza makers and see how the law compares with existing regulations in Naples, Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Use ChatGPT for the Tedious Parts of My Job?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on using artificial intelligence to assist with mundane tasks at work.
content: I’m a writer and a college professor at a small college, and I recently became chair of the English department. I usually love to write, but when it comes to administrative documents, I struggle — and this new role asks for a lot of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Lawrence Turman, 96, Dies; Producer Spotted a Winner in ‘The Graduate’
description: He was relatively new to the business when he was struck by an obscure novel and turned it into the biggest film of 1967.
content: Lawrence Turman, who as a novice movie producer in 1963 read about a novel by a largely unknown writer named Charles Webb, took a $1,000 option on it and thus set in motion the making of “The Graduate,” the landmark film that helped define the 1960s and the antihero genre, died on Saturday at his home in the Woodland Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: A High-Profile Australia-English Cricket Series
description: More than 150 years ago, an Australian tour to England captured the attention of Britons.
content: This week, Australia has, not for the first time, been convulsed by a major cricket controversy that divided cricket fans in England and Australia. (It invited commMore than 150 years ago, a different Australian tour captured the attention of Britons.ent even from the Australian prime minister, Anthony Albanese: “Same old Aussies — always winning!”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Gen X Is in Charge. Don’t Make a Big Deal About It.
description: The original “latchkey kids” are grown up, in the boss’s seat and ready to make the rules. If that’s OK?
content: The average age of incoming C.E.O.s is around 54. While American government remains squarely in the hands of baby boomers — and while its leadership, at least in certain branches, becomes noticeably older — corporate boardrooms are undergoing a transition. It’s Gen X’s moment, that generation most known for being crowded out of sweeping cultural age analyses by millennials on one end and boomers on the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Setting a Table for Alfresco Dining Is Easy: Here’s How.
description: The interior designer Young Huh offers a step-by-step guide to entertaining outdoors with playfulness and style.
content: On a beautiful summer day, you don’t need much of an excuse to dine outdoors — especially if you’ve got a garden, patio or deck surrounded by greenery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Big Number: 19
description: G.M.'s sales were 19 percent higher in the second quarter than a year earlier, as it overcame supply shortages and higher interest rates.
content: G.M.'s sales were 19 percent higher in the second quarter than a year earlier, as it overcame supply shortages and higher interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

title: America’s House of the Moment
description: In a divided country, a clean look and a neutral color palette is the aesthetic comforting communities around the country.
content: In a divided country, a clean look and a neutral color palette is the aesthetic comforting communities around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Does Diversity Actually Work at College? We Asked 10 Young Black Americans.

title: Sleep Better at Every Age
description: Sleep needs shift throughout the lifespan. Experts offer tips to get more rest —  no matter how old you are.
content: Sleep needs shift throughout the lifespan. Experts offer tips to get more rest —  no matter how old you are.

author: By Frank Lehman
title: How to Write Music for Rolling Boulders
description: From “Indiana Jones” to “Star Wars,” you know John Williams’s movie themes. But some of his best music has barely been heard.
content: From “Indiana Jones” to “Star Wars,” you know John Williams’s movie themes. But some of his best music has barely been heard.

description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: What 120 Degrees Looks Like in One of Mexico’s Hottest Cities

title: The ‘Whisper Listing’ Gets Louder
description: Wealthy homeowners who want to avoid attention often try to sell their homes privately. But a tight housing market has led more agents to pursue this tactic.
content: Wealthy homeowners who want to avoid attention often try to sell their homes privately. But a tight housing market has led more agents to pursue this tactic.
